question: A.01 Which ONE is true about “subcritical multiplication”? As the reactor approaches criticality, the parameter
A.02 Which ONE of the following is the approximated time for xenon-135 to decay away to provide a clean, xenon free core, assuming the reactor ran for 1 week for 24 hours? _______ after shutdown.

A.03 The reactor is shutdown with a keff of 0.952. Initial power is 250 mW. The operator withdraws a control rod thereby adding 110 cents of reactivity. What would be the new power level? Given β=0.007.
A.04 Which ONE is true about "excess reactivity"?

answers.answer: a. Ensures that the reactor can be shut down from any condition of operation
answers.feedback: REF:TS Section 3.1.4, pg. 15 (Answer for a and b is shutdown margin)    DOE Handbook part 2, module 3, p. 50 (Answer for c is control rod worth)

answers.answer: b. Ensures that the fuel temperature safety limit will not be exceeded
answers.feedback: REF:TS Section 3.1.4, pg. 15 (Answer for a and b is shutdown margin)    DOE Handbook part 2, module 3, p. 50 (Answer for c is control rod worth)

answers.answer: c. Is the change in reactivity caused by control rod motion
answers.feedback: REF:TS Section 3.1.4, pg. 15 (Answer for a and b is shutdown margin)    DOE Handbook part 2, module 3, p. 50 (Answer for c is control rod worth)

answers.answer:
d. Is the amount of reactivity in excess of the amount of reactivity needed to make the reactor
critical
answers.feedback: REF:TS Section 3.1.4, pg. 15 (Answer for a and b is shutdown margin)    DOE Handbook part 2, module 3, p. 50 (Answer for c is control rod worth)

question: A.05 What is the kinetic energy range of a thermal neutron?

answers.feedback: REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 1, Module 2, Neutron Moderation, pg. 23
REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 1, Module 2, Neutron Moderation, pg. 23

question: A.06 The ideal moderator has ___________ atomic mass for large fractional energy loss per collision; ___________ neutron scattering cross section, so the distance between collisions is small; and a ___________ absorption cross section so that the thermal utilization of the neutrons is dependent primarily on the characteristics of the fuel.
A.07 Which ONE is true about “reflectors”?

answers.answer: b. Have a high neutron absorption cross section
c. Limit the chain reaction by absorbing neutrons
d. Flatten the neutron flux profile of a reactor core

question: A.08 The term “macroscopic cross section” is defined as:

answers.answer: a. The average distance travelled by a neutron between interactions in a material.
b. An indication of energy loss per collision.
c. The probability of neutron interaction per centimeter of travel in a material.
d. The effective cross sectional area of a single nucleus presented to an oncoming neutron.

question: A.09 The reactor is operating at a constant power of 300kW. The reactor is scrammed by the sudden insertion of control rods worth 7% Δk/k in reactivity. What is the power (prompt drop) immediately after scram?

answers.feedback: REF: Given P0 = 300 kW, then P1 =  = . .. . 300 = 29.18 kW

question: A.10 Which one of the following is the MAJOR source of energy released during fission?

answers.answer: a. Kinetic energy of the fission neutrons.
answers.feedback: REF: Burns, Section 3.2.1, and Table 3.2, pg. 3-4 and 3-5

answers.answer: b. Kinetic energy of the fission fragments.
answers.feedback: REF: Burns, Section 3.2.1, and Table 3.2, pg. 3-4 and 3-5

answers.answer: c. Decay of the fission fragments.
answers.feedback: REF: Burns, Section 3.2.1, and Table 3.2, pg. 3-4 and 3-5
REF: Burns, Section 3.2.1, and Table 3.2, pg. 3-4 and 3-5

question: A.11 You start with a cold critical reactor and you insert a control rod to change the keff=0.994.  How much reactivity was inserted by the control rods in units of cents? Given β=0.007.
A.12 Which ONE of the following factors is not affected by the amount of moderator in the reactor?

answers.feedback:
REF: Reed Training Manual (September 2009), Section 10.5, pg. 167. The fuel utilization
factor (also called the reproduction factor) is not affected by the moderator since it is purely a function of the nuclear characteristics of 235U.

question: A.14 Reactor period is defined as:

answers.answer: a. The time required for a reactor to change by a factor of e
b. The time required for the reactor power to double
c. The number of factors of ten that reactor power changes in one minute
d. The fraction of all neutrons that are born as delayed neutrons

question: A.15 Which ONE of the following has the lowest thermal neutron cross section?

answers.feedback: REF:Burns, Table 2.5, pg. 2-59. Also, Table 8.1, pg. 8-2
REF:Burns, Table 2.5, pg. 2-59. Also, Table 8.1, pg. 8-2

question: A.16 Which ONE is true about the four factor formula?

answers.answer: a. Neutron leakages can be reduced by increasing the size of the core.
b. Neutron leakages can be reduced by using a reflector.
c. Neutron leakages can be reduced by increasing moderator temperature.
d. There is no leakage term. The reactor is considered to be infinite in size.

question: A.17 Which ONE defines an integral rod worth curve?

answers.answer: a. Conforms to an axial flux shape.

b. Represents the cumulative area under the differential curve starting from the bottom of the
core.
c. Any point on the curve represents the amount of reactivity that one inch of rod motion would insert at that position in the core.
d. Reactivity is highest at the top of the core and lowest at bottom of the core.

question: A.18 Which ONE of the following describes the term prompt jump?

answers.answer: a. A rapid rise in power level due to an increase in the production of prompt neutrons.
b. A reactor which has attained criticality on prompt neutrons alone.
c. A reactor which is critical using both prompt and delayed neutrons.
d. A negative reactivity insertion which is less than keff.

question: A.19 Xenon-135 is formed directly by decay of ___________.
A.20 The term “delayed neutron” is defined as:

answers.answer: a. A neutron born directly from fission.
b. A neutron in equilibrium with its surroundings.
c. A neutron born due to decay of a fission product.
d. A neutron at an energy level greater than its surroundings.
